Award.AwardTitle: Flow-Induced Disentanglement in Shear and Elongational Flows of Entangled Polymers: A Hi-Fidelity Molecular Simulation Study

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Edwards, Brian
Proposal Number: 1602890

The goal of the proposed research is to understand the behavior of macromolecules (like polymers or proteins) and the way that these macromolecules get entangled and disentangled when the fluid velocity is high. While this is a fundamental problem that can be answered by observations at the molecular scale, it can have significant macroscopic effects that are important during the processing of fluids common in the petrochemical and the food industry, e.g., polymers, surfactants, and liquid crystals.

Many theories have been proposed to explain the microstructural responses of these complex liquids under flow, but each invariably diverged from experiment at high strain rates. Recent evidence suggests that part of the reason for these divergences is that most flow models track bulk-average properties that have effectively discarded the short-timescale dynamical phenomena of the individual molecules. It has recently been observed via nonequilibrium molecular dynamics (NEMD) simulations of moderately-entangled polyethylene liquids that a remarkable dynamical response occurs at high strain rates in both shear and elongational flows: the polymeric liquid experiences a dramatic decrease in the number of chain entanglements, which leads to a network of highly-stretched chains that form effective tube-like structures through which neighboring chains experience anisotropic diffusion. In shear dominated flows, this ultimately leads to chain rotation and retraction cycles, which give rise to characteristic timescales that are much shorter than the reptation time of the liquid. This project will study this behavior using an unprecedented suite of NEMD and Dissipative Particle Dynamics (DPD) simulations of polyethylene liquids with up to 50 entanglements per chain. In addition, the knowledge gained will be harvested to develop a mesoscopic anisotropic diffusion model that can be applied to high strain-rate flows. Results of the proposed work could contribute to more efficient modeling of existing processes and to the design of new fluid materials, or the processes to manufacture them. Data resulting from this work will become available to the research community through the PolyHub storage site. There are also outreach and education activities planned that involve the development of educational modules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at understanding the flow properties of industrially-relevant polymer solutions and melts that are used to form a wide variety of consumer products ranging from low-tech containers to high-tech electronic components. These products are typically processed in the liquid state, and the processing conditions of flow and thermal gradient greatly influence the physical and chemical properties of the final, solidified products.

In this study, we performed atomistic simulations of both polymer melts and solutions under shear and elongational flows to understand the molecular-scale physics of the flow on the fluid dynamics of the simulated materials. The key feature of these simulations was the detailed atomistic model used for the polymers which allowed us, with access to the world’s largest computers, to study dynamical phenomena at very small length and time scales spanning microscopic time scales up to milliseconds. We discovered that flow-induced disentanglement in these materials led to molecular-scale motions, such as semi-periodic chain rotation and retraction cycles, which greatly influenced the fluid properties of the liquids and led to physical explanations for experimentally observed phenomena that had not been previously explained, such as the plateau modulus in steady shear flow and the evolution of shear-banded structures. In addition, under elongational flows it was discovered that polymer melts experience a coil-stretch transition, as originally predicted 50 years ago by Nobel Laureate Pierre de Gennes, which resulted in a flow-induced phase transition based solely on the configurations of the constituent polymer macromolecules. This led to further results which demonstrated in-situ flow-induced crystallization in both solutions and melts for the first time, and the development of phase diagrams for the various physical states of these liquids with respect to temperature and flow rate.

Results from this research project have been disseminated widely throughout the technological community including 11 articles in refereed archival journals, 16 conference presentations (3 invited), and 5 invited seminars at national universities and national laboratories. To date, over 40 citations of these journal articles have already appeared in the technical literature (as per Google Scholar), which is truly remarkably for research that is less than a few years old. This work has already received great attention due to the novelty and unexpected nature of the results, and new theories of polymer fluid dynamics are now being developed based on these findings.

Modified by: Brian J Edwards
